title: Question 86

children: A 29-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for fever and subacute onset of lumbar back pain that radiates down his legs, with numbness and weakness. Symptoms began 3 days ago and have progressively worsened. He has type 1 diabetes and a history of intravenous drug use. Medications are basal and prandial insulin.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.6 °C (101.5 °F); the remaining vital signs are normal. There is spinal tenderness in the lumbar region on palpation. The lower extremities have decreased sensation to touch, diminished reflexes, and 3/5 muscle strength.
Laboratory studies show a
leukocyte count
/L). Blood cultures are pending.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
The three most common atraumatic spinal emergencies are spinal epidural abscess, cauda equina syndrome, and spontaneous spinal epidural hematoma.
MRI is the imaging modality of choice to identify the cause, location, and extent of spinal injury.
The most appropriate initial step in management is MRI of the entire spine (
Option D

). Atraumatic spinal emergencies are most commonly seen first by emergency department clinicians or primary care specialists. The three most common atraumatic spinal emergencies are spinal epidural abscess, cauda equina syndrome, and spontaneous spinal epidural hematoma. Specific signs and symptoms can provide clues as to the cause of compression. The presence of fever and focal back pain and tenderness, especially in patients who have had recent back instrumentation or have a history of intravenous drug use, may indicate an epidural abscess. A history of cancer and focal back pain should raise concern for metastatic disease or pathologic vertebral fracture. Anticoagulant use raises the risk of compression from an epidural hematoma, particularly in the setting of recent back instrumentation or excessive anticoagulation. Spinal epidural abscess most commonly results from hematogenous dissemination, with
S. aureus
accounting for approximately 50% of infections; streptococcus and gram-negative bacilli (such as
Escherichia coli

) are also implicated. Predisposing factors for bacteremia include endocarditis, injection drug use, long-term intravenous catheters (hemodialysis catheters, central lines), diabetes, and urinary tract infection. Spinal epidural abscess can also occur after neurosurgical procedures (spinal fusion, epidural catheter placement) or paraspinal injection. Patients usually develop localized pain at the site of infection that later radiates down the spine or into the legs. Blood cultures should be obtained before starting empiric antibiotics, but antibiotics should not be delayed by other diagnostic testing. MRI is the imaging modality of choice to identify location and extent of the abscess and is the preferred imaging modality for other causes of spine injury. The entire spine should be visualized because infection, bleeding, or metastatic cancer may be multifocal. Decompressive surgery followed by culture-directed long-term antibiotics is the treatment of choice for epidural abscess.
Cerebrospinal fluid analysis and culture (
Option A
) rarely provides a bacteriologic diagnosis, and lumbar puncture is contraindicated because of the risk of entering the infected space and contaminating the spinal fluid.
When MRI is not feasible, CT myelography (
Option B
) can show compressive myelopathy but often does not reveal the cause of compression and thus is not most appropriate.
Lumbar spine radiography (
Option C

) may show evidence of vertebral body infection, such as osteomyelitis, but these findings can take weeks to manifest and are inferior to MRI or CT myelography in the diagnosis of spinal epidural abscess.

references: Babu JM, Patel SA, Palumbo MA, et al. Spinal emergencies in primary care practice. Am J Med. 2019;132:300-6.
